occupation: Principal Strategist at Three Little Birds Agency
headline: Nonprofit Technology Expert | PledgeNoHate.tech | Strategy | Ecosystems/Partnerships | Podcast
summary:
• Detail-oriented problem solver, systems thinker, and blue-sky strategist  
• Highly motivated, intellectually curious self-starter laser focused on execution
• Proven collaborator and creator of enterprise-scale initiatives
• Adept verbal and written communicator to C-level executives and mass audiences
• CRM systems expert with certified Salesforce specialization
• Over twenty-five years nonprofit experience and technology management expertise
• Racial justice research/communication, and LGBT organizing experience

We can, and must, do better. Strive for that place where what seems impossible becomes real. Be the agent provocateur and hold the value of what uplifts all people, organizations, and our discourse. Re-center ourselves in what is right, what elevates us all and our communities, and not just what is profitable. Find equity over equality. Build to sustain and not simply win, and play the long game.

experiences.title: Principal, Problem Solver, and Chief Entrepreneurial Officer (CEO)
experiences.description:
• CRM implementation and technology adoption consulting for nonprofit organizations

Solving hard problems collaboratively with the impact economy regarding the use, ethical use, implementation, integration, and leadership of technology, including the Microsoft and Salesforce platforms, CRM, the Nonprofit Common Data Model, and the global nonprofit technology ecosystem.

This program recognizes exceptional individuals within the Salesforce community for their leadership, knowledge, and ongoing contributions: https://medium.com/@salesforce/a-huge-welcome-to-our-new-class-of-salesforce-mvps-f6abead0d9b0

Summer '15: It's time again to recognize a brand new group of MVPs! We have 15 new MVPs being awarded along with 35 re-awarded MVPs who will hold the MVP title for another year. The MVP Program has been around since December 2010 and recognizes exceptional individuals within the Salesforce Community for their leadership, expertise, and ongoing contributions.

recommendations:
Jamie Mueller



Tracy is one of the most impressive people I've ever met. Their ability to see the future, understand the complexity, and find a pathway to get through it all to realize the grand vision is inspiring and a priceless asset to any organization or company. Tracy came into Bonterra ready and ABLE to take us to the next level, and within a short time at the company, our teams were headed towards something pretty great because of them. 
Tracy is your person if you want someone who can accelerate progress, challenge the status quo, and find the pathways to get to your BHAG. I'm fortunate to have met them, and I can't wait to see what comes next!

Channing Kennedy



I met Tracy at a very crucial turning point in my life — my first job in the nonprofit sector, in a new city, in a position where I was expected to have far more responsibility than the title indicated. If it weren't for Tracy, I absolutely think I would have disappeared within six months. But instead, that position became the first step in a life-changing career for me. Part of this is simply that Tracy is wonderfully supportive and honest, as a coworker and as a friend. But more than that is the lessons I learned from working with them and seeing how they work. Let me see if I can summarize them. 

To be clear, they said absolutely none of this to me in so many words. But this is what stayed with me from our working relationship.

• Don't get distracted by shiny things. (There are many different types of shiny things.) The purpose of your work is not things. It is people.
• If you solve someone's problem, and they can't figure out how to use your solution, you have done the opposite of solving their problem.
• Don't make guesses about how people do things. Go see. You'll be surprised.
• Be loyal to your coworkers. Your coworkers are people.
• Get your work done while you're at work.
• Cultivate and maintain a hobby outside of work and keep it sacred.
• Treat yourself like you matter. You are people.

These sound simple, but in practice, they contradict many of the messages I've gotten from the rest of the industry. Have I followed these guidelines at every step of my career? Absolutely not, and I've regretted it every time I've strayed. It's not easy! But it's worth the effort.

I'll always be grateful that Tracy was there as a role model during this crucial time in my life. They are and will always be someone I turn to when I want to know what the real deal is, from someone who prioritizes people. Thanks, TK.
